creator: colonel_angel2004@yahoo.com
text:
I've had all I can personally take... If Apache wasn't so highly recommended and
the fact that it's the main stream web server for Linux, I wouldn't use it.

The documentation on proxying is not very helpful to the newbies.

For example, it only gives you brief conjectures of what to do, but no real
examples to follow.

Next, it seems very much like the proxying is turned on, even if you don't use
the mod_proxy.so module.

The only thing I found after NUMEROUS hours is a "NoProxy aaa.bbb.ccc.ddd
www.somedomain.com" type of thing.

While it is supposed to improve performance of websites, it however is a
security flaw by allowing non-authorized users, especially PORN sites to use the
web server as a proxy service for their own use.

Now to my dilemma...

For my logging, it's showing people as using my server as a proxy service, even
thought it's turned off and it doesn't seem to include the module for proxying
(mod_proxy.so).

For those of us that are not as "savvy" as those of you who will read this, we
are needing a way to completely disable this feature in clear and concise
instructions.

I'm using Mandriva 2005 Limited, with Apache 2.0.53.  

I don't want people using my server for their own needs, but my own.

Lastly, I had to spend at least 2 days to find "NoProxy", but even that has to
be used with mod_proxy.so.

So, proxying should be a completely "optional" feature, not one that's
automatically there and turned on.  It should be an added on module that people
have to download or compile it with Apache.

You can view my webalizer stats @ http://www.netdesignconceptions.com/usage/ 
There shouldn't be anything other than my site on URL's, but yet there's...
Yahoo and Sun Microsystems on my URL's.

Please help before I go entirely insane!!!!!!!

You appear to be looking for ProxyRequests, which features very prominently in 
the mod_proxy documentation, as well as in third-party articles such as mine 
at ApacheWeek.  
  
Please ask support questions in a user support forum.
